abstract: Marki Flannery of Partners in Care answer questions about the costs of home health aides, the intimate strangers who often make it possible for our parents to remain in their homes.
snippet: Marki Flannery of Partners in Care answer questions about the costs of home health aides, the intimate strangers who often make it possible for our parents to remain in their homes.
lead_paragraph: Part two of a three-part series on home health aides, to be published on Tuesdays in The New Old Age.  Last week Marki Flannery, the president of Partners in Care, an affiliate of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, discussed the advantages of hiring a home health aide from an agency. This week she picks up where she left off, answering questions about the costs of home health aides, the intimate strangers who often make it possible for our parents to remain in their homes, even when they need help or supervision day and night.   (Photo: Marki Flannery of Partners in Care. (Janet Charles))   Q. What does it cost to hire round-the-clock help, and what is the most economical way to do it?   A. When it comes to needing care 24/7, the first thing you have to do is define exactly what level of care you need. Does your mom need a home health aide to monitor her all day and all night, or do you need a home health aide for your mom only when she is awake?  We will help you figure out what you need by asking how well your mom sleeps at night; how many times she gets up; what her sleeping patterns are. We will also figure out with you if the home environment has a suitable place for the home health aide to sleep, and if the aide who is "living-in" will be able to get some hours of uninterrupted sleep and a couple of hours a day "off-duty."   If you want a "live-in" home health aide who will be in the home 24 hours a day, but who will have time off to sleep and for personal time, then we suggest two aides to cover the seven days in a week -- one who works for four days and another who works the remaining three days.   This shared approach keeps the cost to you as low as possible, because when one aide works more than 40 hours during a seven-day week, we are required by law to pay that aide additional money for each hour worked over 40.   So, here is how the math works:  We charge you for one aide working three days at 14 hours per day, for a total of 42 hours. Forty hours are charged at our hourly rate (currently $18.50 in New York City), and two hours are charged at the overtime rate (currently $23.05) and, we charge you for the other aide working four days at 14 hours per day for a total of 56 hours, with 40 hours being charged at our hourly rate and 16 hours charged at the overtime rate. Thus, a week of round-the-clock help costs $1,894.90.   Of course you could request that one aide work more than four days in a row, but then the costs increase. Or, you could increase the number of aides and have each aide work just 40 hours per week or less, but then you have more aides working for you.  There are times, however, when two aides simply can't cover the full seven-day week. If your mom truly needs the aide to be awake every hour of the day, we assign two aides to each 24-hour period, one working from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. and the second working the 8 p.m. to 8 a.m. shift. In this case, to cover the full week, we would assign four aides. Two of them would exceed the 40 hours per week limit, each having to work 48 hours during the week. So, you would have a total of 16 hours charged at the overtime rate. In this scenario, a week of care costs $3,328.80.   These options get you the care you need from a licensed home health care agency at the lowest possible cost and keep the number of home health aides as low as possible. Other options can be worked out but likely will result in increasing the number of aides working for you.   Q. How much money does your average aide make, and what benefits do you offer, compared to the industry at large?   A. We pay our home health aides by the hour, on a graduated scale. That means that the hourly pay rate increases the longer a home health aide works for us. Entry level aides earn $8 per hour, and aides who have worked with us for a few years or more earn up to $13 per hour. According to published information, the national average wage for home health aides is $9.11 per hour. Our average wage is higher.   You may be wondering why we charge you more than the hourly rate we pay our home health aides, and the answer lies in the support we provide to our employees. All of our aides are eligible for individual health benefits, including vision, dental and prescription drug coverage, at no cost to them. We also offer our aides pension benefits, paid vacations and sick time, and we provide uniforms as well.   In addition, all of our aides are offered continuing education and have career advancement opportunities. While we have many home health aides who never want to stop going to people's homes and helping them live a better life, we also have aides who move up the career ladder to become nurses, supervisors and managers. And of course, there are the usual business expenses, including rent, insurance, recruitment, equipment, staff to oversee the care provided and administrative staff.  All of these things account for our success in keeping home health aides working with us for years. There is a lot of turnover in our industry, and we see it, too. But estimates put the national average at 40 percent to 60 percent, and, year-after-year, we see a turnover rate of less than half the national average. We celebrated our 25th anniversary in 2008 and are very proud of the fact that we have 12 home health aides who have been with us for every one of those years. We have 27 aides who have worked with us for 20 years, another 33 who have 15 years of service, 112 with 10 years and more than 2,100 who have been here at least five years.   Q. Home health aides from licensed agencies must follow certain rules that restricts what they can do. Why is this so?   A. The rules and regulations that govern what a certified home health aide can and can't do exist primarily to protect the patient and family. People may choose to hire an unlicensed individual and not have to follow the New York State rules and regulations but then, as I have suggested before, the risk factor is likely to increase in any number of ways.   We recently took on the case of a patient whose family had first hired someone recommended to them by a neighbor. This person, not certified and not trained, used the wrong dressing on an open wound, causing considerable harm and pain to the patient. This mistake is far less likely to happen with a certified home health aide. If the patient had been with us from the beginning, the proper treatment would have been prescribed by the doctor and managed by the nurse in cooperation with the patient's physician, and the aide would have received proper instruction about what needed to be done.  In another case, an adult daughter called us after her mom, who suffered from both Alzheimer's and congestive heart failure, was admitted to the hospital as a result of an adverse reaction to medications. The daughter had initially hired a person to be with her mom at home and give her the medications she needed. As the mother's medical condition deteriorated, her medication routine became more complex. Unfortunately, the multiple medications didn't work well together, and her mom had to be hospitalized. The person hired by the woman's daughter could not explain to the doctors exactly what meds she had given to the patient and when they were administered. While certified home health aides in New York State can give medications to most patients, they cannot administer medications to patients who are not aware of what they are taking and why, but nurses can. So in this case, we would have provided both an aide and a nurse, ensuring the medications would be properly administered.  We sometimes hear from people that hired a trustworthy person on their own, because he or she can do the food shopping for an elderly parent while a certified home health aide from a licensed agency can't. Not true. At Partners in Care, we handle grocery shopping for patients all the time, but we do so using a system of checks and balances to ensure that our client's money is spent on what they want. If the patient wants us to use cash, we put a limit on how much. We also require our aide to keep the receipts and, of course, return the change. We won't allow our aides to use a patient's debit or credit card or PIN number. Most often, we use the online credit card purchasing systems available in a market, such as Fresh Direct, and use home delivery.   Another concern we hear goes like this: "I want someone who will pick up my mom after she falls, not leave her on the floor until emergency medical services arrives. And a certified home health aide won't do that." Well, this concern is true. A certified home health aide is taught that there is greater risk in lifting or moving an elderly person who has fallen than there is in waiting for the appropriate medical team to arrive. At the same time, a professionally trained aide can usually differentiate a minor fall from a more serious fall that requires professional medical assistance. So, it may not sound like something you want -- leaving your fallen mom in her prone position until E.M.S. arrives - but if the certified home health aide has made that determination, there is likely a very serious reason for doing so.   More next week on hiring and managing home health aides, who will be needed in huge numbers as America rapidly ages.

abstract: More and more, ministering to the terminally ill in hospice care is likely to be nonsectarian, or even secular.
snippet: More and more, ministering to the terminally ill in hospice care is likely to be nonsectarian, or even secular.
lead_paragraph: Some of the hospice patients talk about their impending deaths, or about God. Most just talk about what people always talk about  unfinished business and unanswered questions: regrets over firing an employee 50 years ago; the pet no one has yet promised to adopt; feeling sick to death of being sick yet not ready to die. About Bach. “How did he dream up that music?” one woman asks.

abstract: The use of Salvia divinorum, a potent hallucinogenic herb, was once limited to revelation seekers in Mexico. Now, the drug is available legally across the U.S.
snippet: The use of Salvia divinorum, a potent hallucinogenic herb, was once limited to revelation seekers in Mexico. Now, the drug is available legally across the U.S.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS  With a friend videotaping, 27-year-old Christopher Lenzini of Dallas took a hit of Salvia divinorum, regarded as the world’s most potent hallucinogenic herb, and soon began to imagine, he said, that he was in a boat with little green men. Mr. Lenzini quickly collapsed to the floor and dissolved into convulsive laughter.

abstract: My husband's "mistress" has given notice. I'll miss her.
snippet: My husband's "mistress" has given notice. I'll miss her.
lead_paragraph: MY 79-year-old husband, the love of my life, is having an “affair” with a young single woman named Jenn. He and I fell in love more than a half century ago and have lived together for 22 years, but I have no regrets about the liaison. Go for it, I say. Be my guest.

abstract: Charlton Heston was really a character actor trapped in the body of leading man.
snippet: Charlton Heston was really a character actor trapped in the body of leading man.
lead_paragraph: One day more than 35 years ago, I pulled into the parking lot of the massive Del Coronado hotel in San Diego when an equally massive figure walked in front of my car, blocking my view because his body filled the entire windshield. It was Charlton Heston, and he strode toward the tennis courts with a purposive authority that brought to mind Moses and Ben Hur, albeit dressed this time in shorts. This was the closest I ever got to Heston in the flesh, although, like hundred of millions of other moviegoers, I saw a great deal of him, sometimes barely clothed (“Planet of the Apes”), on the big screen.
headline.main: Larger Than Life: Charlton Heston

abstract: CORNVILLE, Arizona — ANY fool can hire an architect to draw up a plan for a house, but it takes a truly inspired fool — which is to say, an artist — to start building and see where the earth and driftwood and shards of broken pottery take him, and an equally impassioned fool — say, a woman in love — to go along and carry the rocks on her back.

abstract: DALLAS — With a friend videotaping, 27-year-old Christopher Lenzini of Dallas took a hit of Salvia divinorum, regarded as the world's most potent hallucinogenic herb, and soon began to imagine, he said, that he was in a boat with little green men. Lenzini quickly collapsed to the floor and dissolved into convulsive laughter.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — With a friend videotaping, 27-year-old Christopher Lenzini of Dallas took a hit of Salvia divinorum, regarded as the world's most potent hallucinogenic herb, and soon began to imagine, he said, that he was in a boat with little green men. Lenzini quickly collapsed to the floor and dissolved into convulsive laughter.

abstract: It was the family jewel, and I was about to give it away.
snippet: It was the family jewel, and I was about to give it away.
lead_paragraph: MY grandfather Harry (my mother’s father) gave my grandmother a relatively inexpensive engagement ring with her birthstone. It wasn’t until many years later, after my grandfather had built a successful shoe store business, that he bought her a 2.5-carat diamond. When my grandmother was in her early 80s and suffering from Alzheimer’s, she became so frail that the ring would slide off her finger, so my grandfather reluctantly took it from her.

abstract: In Britain, a controversial proposal to allow the merging of the DNA of two separate species.
snippet: In Britain, a controversial proposal to allow the merging of the DNA of two separate species.
lead_paragraph: This week, a complex and controversial piece of legislation began to make its way through the British parliament. One of the provisions of the bill permits the creation of “savior siblings” — children created via in vitro fertilization (I.V.F.) to ensure their tissues will match those of a sick older brother or sister, in order that the new child could provide, say, a bone marrow transplant. (Conceiving a child the old-fashioned way doesn’t guarantee a tissue match.) Another is a reduction of the legal time-limit on abortion, which up to now has been 24 weeks.
headline.main: Enter, the Cybrids

abstract: Catching up with Jackie from the block, along with Peachie, GeeGee and Starr. Twenty years ago they lit up a patch of Brooklyn sidewalk.
snippet: Catching up with Jackie from the block, along with Peachie, GeeGee and Starr. Twenty years ago they lit up a patch of Brooklyn sidewalk.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY years ago, six girls lit up a troubled Brooklyn block. Gunfire could be heard in the distance. There was a stream of visitors to the apartments of drug dealers. But these girls had claimed a patch of sidewalk in front of their building, and from April to October, on a strip of Parkside Avenue just east of Prospect Park, these 8- and 11-year-olds were unstoppable.

abstract: In this lesson, students test and reflect on how the brain receives, interprets and translates contradictory verbal and auditory cues into movement. abstract: A new drug aimed at treating schizophrenia turns its focus away from dopamine and instead on the effects of glutamate, another powerful neurotransmitter.
snippet: A new drug aimed at treating schizophrenia turns its focus away from dopamine and instead on the effects of glutamate, another powerful neurotransmitter.
lead_paragraph: NORTH WALES, Pa.  SCIENTISTS who develop drugs are familiar with disappointment  brilliant theories that don’t pan out or promising compounds derailed by unexpected side effects. They are accustomed to small steps and wrong turns, to failure after failure  until, in a moment, with hard work, brainpower and a lot of luck, all those little failures turn into one big success.

abstract: Thousands of groups around the world, like the Michael J. Fox Foundation, are dedicated to eliminating one particular disease or another.
snippet: Thousands of groups around the world, like the Michael J. Fox Foundation, are dedicated to eliminating one particular disease or another.
lead_paragraph: A few years after Michael J. Fox revealed that he had Parkinson’s disease, he attended the annual charity auction for the Robin Hood Foundation, a New York philanthropy financed largely from donations by wealthy hedge fund managers. Mr. Fox was in his late 30s at the time. He had been living with Parkinson’s since 1991, when he received the diagnosis at the age of 30, but had kept quiet about it while he continued his acting career. It was only in 1998, when his symptoms  the uncontrollable tremors and halting speech that characterize those with Parkinson’s  had become pronounced enough that he could no longer continue with his hit show “Spin City” that he finally let the news out.

abstract: Fifteen film actors whose performances in 2007 marked a career-defining moment — and set them above the rest.
snippet: Fifteen film actors whose performances in 2007 marked a career-defining moment — and set them above the rest.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, at the Sundance Film Festival, a star was born, but almost no one noticed. Well, actually, a few studio executives who saw “Hard Candy” raved about the performance of the unknown Ellen Page  she played an avenging, psychopathic 14-year-old who entices and then violently tortures a would-be pedophile. But the movie was so relentlessly disturbing (at one point, Page’s character ties her enemy down and slowly begins to castrate him) that when “Hard Candy” was released the following year, no one went to see it. What the audience missed then is what they later found in “Juno”  the birth of a different sort of actress. Unlike her glamour-girl peers who double as tabloid superstars, Page, who is now 20, is a tomboy  her on-screen persona is sharp, clear-eyed, determined and self-consciously original. In “Hard Candy,” she managed to be adorable and persuasive while wielding a large knife; in 2007, that same spirit and charm animated “Juno,” a kind of fairy tale about a pregnant 16-year-old who decides to have the baby and give it to the couple (in the end, half the couple) she chooses. In “Juno,” the lack of realism  no one questions Juno’s decision  and the lack of politics are trumped by the overwhelming appeal of Page’s acting. She is so alive on screen  so unique, so ingratiating  that she makes the character, and the entire film, believable.

abstract: Mickey Rourke gets his career off the mat with “The Wrestler.” But there is plenty that he’s still battling.
snippet: Mickey Rourke gets his career off the mat with “The Wrestler.” But there is plenty that he’s still battling.
lead_paragraph: YOU MEET MICKEY, you can’t help liking him. He rescues abused dogs! He cries a lot: over his stepfather’s supposed abuse; the loss of his brother to cancer and his dogs to old age; the failure of his marriage to the actress Carré Otis. He admits he destroyed his own career, because, as he puts it: “I was arrogant. . . . I wasn’t smart enough or educated enough” to deal with stardom. He is candid about the people he has crossed paths with: Nicole Kidman is “an ice cube”; Michael Cimino, the director of “Heaven’s Gate,” “is crazy” and “nuts”; and the producer Samuel Goldwyn Jr. is “a liar.”

abstract: How the publisher Louise Hay unified psychics, mindhealers, angel therapists and positive thinkers of all varieties into a self-help spirituality empire.
snippet: How the publisher Louise Hay unified psychics, mindhealers, angel therapists and positive thinkers of all varieties into a self-help spirituality empire.
lead_paragraph: LOUISE HAY IS ONE OF THE BEST-SELLING AUTHORS IN HISTORY, and none of the women who have sold more  like J. K. Rowling, Danielle Steel and Barbara Cartland  owned a publishing empire. They did not change the spiritual landscape of America and several of its Western allies. They were not pregnant at 15 and they did not lack high-school diplomas. Finer writers they may have been (depending on your taste), and wealthier women, but it would be hard to argue that any was more interesting than Louise Hay.

abstract: An article on Tuesday about the use of antipsychotic drugs in dementia patients misspelled the names of two drugs in a different class, sometimes used to treat the symptoms of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. They are Exelon and Namenda, not Exalon and Menamda.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the use of antipsychotic drugs in dementia patients misspelled the names of two drugs in a different class, sometimes used to treat the symptoms of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. They are Exelon and Namenda, not Exalon and Menamda.
